metadata.subject: English
metadata.document_title: English programmes of study: key stage 3
metadata.notes: Well-structured curriculum with clear domains (Reading, Writing, Grammar/Vocabulary, Spoken English). Builds systematically on KS2. Emphasizes literary analysis, formal writing, and sophisticated language use.

domains.description: Developing appreciation of literature and critical reading skills through challenging texts including fiction, non-fiction, poetry, drama, and Shakespeare. Focuses on comprehension, inference, critical analysis, and literary comparison.
domains.curriculum_context: Reading at KS3 requires pupils to read and engage critically with a wide range of texts across literature, literary non-fiction and non-fiction — including pre-nineteenth century, nineteenth century, and contemporary fiction and non-fiction from the English literary heritage and other cultures. The statutory curriculum requires pupils to develop the habit of reading widely and often, for both pleasure and information, and to draw on their reading to inform their own writing. Pupils are expected to analyse the effect of authors' choices of structure, form, grammar and vocabulary — moving beyond identifying features to evaluating their effect on a reader. At KS3, pupils encounter canonical literary texts including novels, plays and poetry, developing a culturally rich frame of reference that prepares them for GCSE literature. Pupils also develop the critical reading skills needed to navigate and evaluate non-fiction, media and digital texts, recognising bias, perspective and rhetorical technique.

domains.description: Writing accurately, fluently, and at length for diverse purposes and audiences. Includes narrative, expository, persuasive, and imaginative writing with focus on structure, planning, and rhetorical devices.
domains.curriculum_context: Writing at KS3 demands that pupils write with increasing independence, precision and creativity across a range of forms and purposes — including narrative, descriptive, expository, analytical and persuasive writing. The statutory curriculum requires pupils to plan, draft, evaluate and redraft their writing, developing an understanding of the craft of writing and the recursive process of improvement through revision. Pupils are expected to develop a personal writing voice — making deliberate stylistic choices about sentence structure, vocabulary and tone — and to adapt their writing to audience, purpose and form with increasing sophistication. At KS3, pupils should extend their control of complex sentence structures, develop the ability to write coherently across multi-paragraph pieces, and use the full range of punctuation taught in primary school with accuracy and deliberate effect.

domains.description: Consolidating and extending grammatical knowledge from KS1-2. Analyzing grammatical features in texts, understanding Standard English, and using sophisticated vocabulary and grammatical constructions consciously.
domains.curriculum_context: Grammar and vocabulary at KS3 formalises and extends pupils' grammatical knowledge from primary school, enabling them to understand language as a systematic, rule-governed system and to use grammatical terminology analytically in their reading and writing. Pupils learn to deploy complex sentence structures — including relative clauses, passive constructions, modal verbs and subjunctive forms — to create specific effects in writing, and to understand how language choices reflect social context and power. The statutory curriculum requires explicit teaching of linguistic and literary terms — figurative language, metaphor, connotation, etymology, register, syntax — that equip pupils to discuss texts precisely and write about language analytically in preparation for GCSE. Pupils are also expected to extend their vocabulary systematically, learning new words from reading and understanding the principles of etymology and morphology that enable them to infer the meaning of unfamiliar words.

domains.description: Speaking confidently and effectively in formal and informal contexts. Includes presentations, debates, performance of scripts and poetry, and using spoken language for learning and discussion.
domains.curriculum_context: Spoken English at KS3 develops pupils' ability to communicate confidently, purposefully and persuasively across a range of formal and informal contexts. Pupils are expected to give well-structured presentations and speeches, using Standard English fluently and adapting their spoken language to audience and purpose. The statutory curriculum requires pupils to participate in structured discussions, seminars and debates — listening attentively, building on others' ideas, and developing their own position through extended oral argument. Drama and role play are used to explore characters, situations and ideas from texts studied, developing pupils' imaginative engagement and their ability to manipulate voice and gesture for communicative effect. By the end of KS3, pupils should be articulate, confident speakers who can hold their own in academic discussion and present persuasive, well-evidenced arguments orally.

objectives.objective_text: Develop an appreciation and love of reading, and read increasingly challenging material independently through reading a wide range of fiction and non-fiction, including in particular whole books, short stories, poems and plays with a wide coverage of genres, historical periods, forms and authors.
sub_requirements: Reading high-quality works from English literature, both pre-1914 and contemporary, including prose, poetry and drama

objectives.objective_text: Choose and read books independently for challenge, interest and enjoyment.
Re-read books encountered earlier to increase familiarity with them and provide a basis for making comparisons.
Understand increasingly challenging texts through learning new vocabulary, relating it explicitly to known vocabulary and understanding it with the help of context and dictionaries.
Understand increasingly challenging texts through making inferences and referring to evidence in the text.
Understand increasingly challenging texts through knowing the purpose, audience for and context of the writing and drawing on this knowledge to support comprehension.
Understand increasingly challenging texts through checking their understanding to make sure that what they have read makes sense.
Read critically through knowing how language, including figurative language, vocabulary choice, grammar, text structure and organisational features, presents meaning.
Read critically through recognising a range of poetic conventions and understanding how these have been used.
Read critically through studying setting, plot, and characterisation, and the effects of these.
Read critically through understanding how the work of dramatists is communicated effectively through performance and how alternative staging allows for different interpretations of a play.
Read critically through making critical comparisons across texts.
Read critically through studying a range of authors, including at least two authors in depth each year.

Write accurately, fluently, effectively and at length for pleasure and information through writing for a wide range of purposes and audiences, including well-structured formal expository and narrative essays.
Write accurately, fluently, effectively and at length for pleasure and information through writing stories, scripts, poetry and other imaginative writing.
Write accurately, fluently, effectively and at length for pleasure and information through writing notes and polished scripts for talks and presentations.

Write accurately, fluently, effectively and at length for pleasure and information through writing a range of other narrative and non-narrative texts, including arguments, and personal and formal letters.
Write accurately, fluently, effectively and at length for pleasure and information through summarising and organising material, and supporting ideas and arguments with any necessary factual detail.

Write accurately, fluently, effectively and at length for pleasure and information through applying their growing knowledge of vocabulary, grammar and text structure to their writing and selecting the appropriate form.

Write accurately, fluently, effectively and at length for pleasure and information through drawing on knowledge of literary and rhetorical devices from their reading and listening to enhance the impact of their writing.
Plan, draft, edit and proof-read through considering how their writing reflects the audiences and purposes for which it was intended.
Plan, draft, edit and proof-read through amending the vocabulary, grammar and structure of their writing to improve its coherence and overall effectiveness.

Plan, draft, edit and proof-read through paying attention to accurate grammar, punctuation and spelling; applying the spelling patterns and rules set out in English Appendix 1 to the key stage 1 and 2 programmes of study for English.

Consolidate and build on their knowledge of grammar and vocabulary through extending and applying the grammatical knowledge set out in English Appendix 2 to the key stage 1 and 2 programmes of study to analyse more challenging texts.
Consolidate and build on their knowledge of grammar and vocabulary through studying the effectiveness and impact of the grammatical features of the texts they read.

Consolidate and build on their knowledge of grammar and vocabulary through drawing on new vocabulary and grammatical constructions from their reading and listening, and using these consciously in their writing and speech to achieve particular effects.

Consolidate and build on their knowledge of grammar and vocabulary through knowing and understanding the differences between spoken and written language, including differences associated with formal and informal registers, and between Standard English and other varieties of English.
Consolidate and build on their knowledge of grammar and vocabulary through using Standard English confidently in their own writing and speech.
Consolidate and build on their knowledge of grammar and vocabulary through discussing reading, writing and spoken language with precise and confident use of linguistic and literary terminology.
Speak confidently and effectively, including through using Standard English confidently in a range of formal and informal contexts, including classroom discussion.
Speak confidently and effectively, including through giving short speeches and presentations, expressing their own ideas and keeping to the point.
Speak confidently and effectively, including through participating in formal debates and structured discussions, summarising and/or building on what has been said.

Speak confidently and effectively, including through improvising, rehearsing and performing play scripts and poetry in order to generate language and discuss language use and meaning, using role, intonation, tone, volume, mood, silence, stillness and action to add impact.

concepts.description: Reading across diverse genres, historical periods, forms, and authors including fiction, non-fiction, poetry, and drama
Engaging with literary texts written before 1914 to understand historical literary traditions
Reading and analyzing modern literary texts to understand current literary forms and themes
Studying two Shakespeare plays to understand Early Modern drama, language, and themes
Reading seminal works from diverse cultures and literary traditions beyond British literature
Choosing appropriate books independently based on challenge, personal interest, and enjoyment
Returning to previously read texts to deepen familiarity and enable critical comparison
Learning sophisticated vocabulary through context, relating to known words, and using dictionaries
Using context clues to determine meaning of unfamiliar words in challenging texts
Making sophisticated inferences about implicit meaning, character motivation, and authorial intent
Supporting interpretations with specific evidence from texts, using quotations effectively
Understanding how the intended purpose and audience shape a text's meaning and form
Understanding texts within their historical, social, and cultural contexts
Actively checking understanding while reading and using strategies to resolve confusion
Identifying and analyzing metaphors, similes, personification, and other figurative devices
Examining how specific word choices create meaning, tone, and effect
Understanding how grammatical structures (sentence types, tense, voice) create meaning and effect
Analyzing how texts are organized (chronologically, thematically, etc.) and its effect on meaning
Identifying poetic forms (sonnet, ballad, free verse), meter, rhyme schemes, and structural patterns
Analyzing how poetic devices (imagery, sound patterns, enjambment) create meaning and effect
Analyzing how settings establish mood, symbolize themes, and influence character and plot
Understanding narrative structure (exposition, rising action, climax, resolution) and its effects
Analyzing how characters are developed through description, dialogue, actions, and relationships
Understanding how plays are communicated through performance elements (acting, staging, direction)
Understanding how different staging choices create different interpretations of dramatic texts
Making critical comparisons between texts in terms of themes, techniques, contexts, and effects
Studying multiple works by the same author to understand their style, themes, and development
Writing structured essays that explain, analyze, or inform using formal academic style
Writing structured narrative essays with clear story elements and academic tone
Writing at length with sustained focus, coherence, and quality
Writing imaginative narratives with developed characters, settings, and plot
Writing dramatic scripts with dialogue, stage directions, and dramatic structure
Writing original poems using poetic devices, forms, and techniques
Writing effective notes and polished scripts for oral presentations and talks
Writing persuasive texts that present claims, evidence, reasoning, and counterarguments
Writing letters in both personal and formal registers with appropriate conventions
Condensing and organizing material to capture key points effectively
Supporting ideas and arguments with relevant factual detail and evidence
Selecting appropriate text forms based on purpose, audience, and context
Applying advanced vocabulary precisely and effectively in writing
Using diverse grammatical structures purposefully to create effect
Using techniques like repetition, rhetorical questions, triads, and emotive language for persuasive effect
Applying literary techniques (imagery, symbolism, alliteration) learned from reading
Adapting language, tone, and style to suit specific audiences
Shaping writing to achieve specific purposes (inform, persuade, entertain, explain)
Improving the logical flow, connections, and overall coherence of writing through revision
Selecting more precise, sophisticated, or effective vocabulary during revision
Reorganizing paragraphs, sections, and arguments to improve overall effectiveness
Applying KS1-2 spelling patterns and rules to spell challenging words accurately
Using punctuation accurately including complex sentences, semicolons, colons, and dashes
Writing with consistent grammatical accuracy including agreement, tense consistency, and correct forms
Analyzing challenging texts by identifying and understanding complex grammatical structures
Understanding and using metalinguistic terms (clause, phrase, modal verb, passive voice, etc.)
Deliberately selecting grammatical constructions and vocabulary to achieve specific effects
Understanding formal and informal registers and when to use each appropriately
Understanding differences between spoken and written language forms and conventions
Understanding Standard English as the formal variety used in education and professional contexts
Understanding dialects, sociolects, and other varieties of English
Consistently using Standard English forms in formal writing
Using Standard English confidently in formal speaking situations
Using precise literary terms (metaphor, symbolism, protagonist, narrative voice, etc.) in discussion
Discussing language and literature using sophisticated terminology and analysis
Recognizing when formal speech is appropriate (presentations, debates, discussions)
Understanding when informal speech is appropriate while maintaining clarity
Organizing speeches and presentations with clear introduction, body, and conclusion
Expressing ideas clearly and concisely in spoken form
Staying on topic and avoiding digression during speeches and presentations
Participating in structured debates following conventions and rules
Contributing effectively to structured classroom and group discussions
Condensing and restating what others have said in discussions
Extending, challenging, or developing ideas contributed by others in discussion
Creating spontaneous dramatic responses and dialogue in role
Practicing and refining performance of dramatic scripts
Performing dramatic and poetic texts with appropriate expression and technique
Using role, intonation, tone, volume, mood, silence, stillness, and action to enhance performance
Using dramatic activities to explore and generate language
Using dramatic performance as a basis for discussing language use and meaning
Developing intrinsic motivation to read independently for enjoyment
Valuing and engaging with the rich tradition of English literature
Persisting with challenging texts and using strategies to overcome difficulties
Developing stamina and persistence to write at length and through drafting process
Viewing writing as improvable through revision rather than as a single draft
Developing confidence to speak in formal contexts without excessive anxiety
Working effectively with peers in discussions, respecting different viewpoints
Reading complete novels, plays, and longer texts rather than extracts only
Engaging deeply with texts through close reading, annotation, and analysis
Planning writing content, structure, and approach before drafting
Creating initial drafts as a stage in the writing process, not as final products
Systematically checking for and correcting errors in spelling, punctuation, and grammar

prerequisite_relationships.rationale: KS2 reading breadth in fiction and non-fiction provides foundation for KS3's wider range including more challenging genres and historical periods
KS2 book selection skills develop into more sophisticated independent selection for challenge at KS3
KS2 inference skills provide foundation for more complex inference required in challenging KS3 texts
KS1 basic vocabulary strategies underpin advanced vocabulary acquisition at KS3
KS2 vocabulary development provides immediate foundation for sophisticated vocabulary work at KS3
KS2 use of textual evidence develops into more sophisticated citation and quotation at KS3
KS2 awareness of purpose and audience deepens into analytical understanding at KS3
KS2 figurative language identification develops into critical analysis of effect at KS3
KS2 poetry understanding provides foundation for sophisticated poetic conventions at KS3
KS2 setting awareness develops into analytical understanding of setting's effects at KS3
KS2 character understanding develops into sophisticated characterization analysis at KS3
KS2 plot understanding provides foundation for analyzing plot structure and effects at KS3
KS2 text comparison skills develop into critical cross-textual analysis at KS3
KS2 non-narrative writing provides foundation for formal expository essays at KS3
KS2 narrative writing develops into more sophisticated creative story writing at KS3
KS1 simple poetry writing provides distant foundation for sophisticated composition at KS3
KS2 poetry writing provides immediate foundation for advanced poetic composition at KS3
KS2 summarization skills develop into more sophisticated condensing of complex material at KS3
KS2 using evidence in writing develops into sophisticated evidence-based argumentation at KS3
KS2 audience awareness provides foundation for sophisticated audience adaptation at KS3
KS2 writing for different purposes develops into conscious purpose awareness at KS3
KS2 evaluation and editing provides foundation for sophisticated revision for coherence at KS3
KS2 spelling patterns and rules directly support advanced spelling accuracy at KS3
KS1 basic punctuation provides foundation for advanced punctuation at KS3
KS2 developing punctuation skills directly support advanced punctuation at KS3
KS1 basic grammatical terminology provides foundation for sophisticated metalinguistic vocabulary at KS3
KS2 grammatical terminology directly supports advanced metalinguistic knowledge at KS3
KS2 sentence structure understanding provides immediate foundation for analyzing complex texts grammatically at KS3
KS2 grammatical features understanding develops into analyzing grammatical effects at KS3
KS2 Standard English use provides foundation for confident, conscious use at KS3
KS1 participating in discussions provides distant foundation for formal spoken contexts at KS3
KS2 presentation skills provide foundation for structured speeches at KS3
KS2 discussion participation develops into structured discussion skills at KS3
KS1 poetry performance provides foundation for sophisticated dramatic and poetic performance at KS3
KS2 drama participation provides immediate foundation for script and poetry performance at KS3
Advanced vocabulary acquisition enables sophisticated vocabulary use in writing
Knowing grammatical terminology enables analysis of grammatical features in texts
Analyzing grammatical structures enables understanding their effects on meaning
Understanding grammatical effects enables conscious use of varied structures in writing
Analyzing figurative language in reading enables applying literary devices in writing
Recognizing poetic conventions enables analyzing how they create effects
Understanding poetic devices and their effects enables composing sophisticated poetry
Making complex inferences supports deeper characterization analysis
Analyzing characterization in reading informs creating developed characters in writing
Analyzing setting effects in reading informs creating effective settings in creative writing
Understanding plot structure enables crafting well-structured narratives
Understanding dramatic performance informs writing effective scripts
Analyzing purpose and audience in reading enables selecting appropriate forms in writing
Understanding audience analysis in reading enables audience awareness in writing
Audience awareness requires understanding register appropriateness
Understanding register enables using Standard English appropriately in speech
Understanding Standard English enables its consistent use in writing
Understanding Standard English enables its confident use in formal speech
Using textual evidence in analysis enables evidence-based argumentation in writing
Evidence-based argumentation skills support effective argumentative writing
Analyzing vocabulary choices in reading enables vocabulary refinement in revision
Understanding text structure in reading informs structural editing in writing
Planning precedes and informs the drafting process
Creating drafts enables revision for coherence
Revision for coherence typically precedes final proof-reading for errors
Re-reading texts for familiarity enables more sophisticated cross-textual comparison
Wide reading breadth provides context for studying specific authors in depth
Script writing understanding supports dramatic improvisation
Improvisation skills can inform and enhance script rehearsal
Rehearsal directly prepares for polished performance
Performing texts provides concrete basis for discussing language use and meaning
Writing presentation scripts informs structuring and organizing speeches
Having clear speech structure helps maintain focus and avoid digression
Summarizing others' contributions is prerequisite to building on their ideas
Knowing grammatical and literary terminology enables metalinguistic discussion
Literary terminology is essential for sophisticated metalinguistic discussion
Understanding historical context is essential for engaging with pre-1914 literature
Understanding Early Modern historical context is crucial for Shakespeare study
Reading resilience is necessary to persist with challenging Shakespeare language
Reading resilience helps students engage with challenging pre-1914 literature
Intrinsic reading motivation supports independent book selection
Writing resilience is essential for developing extended writing stamina
Extended writing stamina enables writing formal essays at length
Revision mindset is necessary for engaging meaningfully in revision for coherence
Speaking confidence enables effective participation in formal debates
Collaborative discussion skills support building on others' ideas respectfully
